I love this game. Many of the negative reviews point out how "unfair" it is, and they don't treat it properly. This game is HARD. But you never have to rely on any sort of randomness to win. There's always something you can (or could) do to make the outcome different.

There is no easy mode. Once you get the gist of your captain, the pollution 0 becomes quite simple and easy, but you must know what you're doing. And even then, you have the increasing pollution to keep the game challenging, and even more the nightmare mode for some real pain.

You have to balance your economy and your ability to defend yourself while still enhancing the city to be able to deal with the following waves. And this is essentially a game of combos. If you pick a little bit of everything to experiment with all the stuff, you are going to lose. And most, if not all, of the mechanics are viable for a core strategy. But you have to commit to them. As you progress into later waves, you must have a heavy synergy strategy, or else at least be only with extremely good cards, getting rid of everything you started and got early too.

This is a very challenging game that can get you many, many hours of fun. If you're in for comboing and getting challenged, I definitely recommend it. If you've never played another rogue-lite deck-building game, I'd recommend another one first before trying this one out (like monster train, griftlands, slay the spire, there are many) because getting the hang of the deck-building basics while getting pressured by the RTS aspect of this game could prove a little overwhelming, even with the extreme slow down given by the game (or full stops) in some decision moments.

Pros:
+ Cute graphics (and sounds if you don't mind squeaky voices)
+ Quite fun tower defense
+ Decently challenging
+ Always something to do

Cons:
- Not much tactical depth
- Stereotype hits soon and hard
- Different characters aren't really very different

It's fun... for the price. An interesting attempt to combine different genres, unfortunately the stereotype hits pretty fast. The game tries to tackle it in the classical manner of providing different characters with different deck, but the problem is the game loop is firmly set. One character gives you resource according to number of buildings, another requires you not to lose units and another yet has you wait till your ratizens finish a chore, but ultimately, you always spam cards as fast as you can, amassing resources and spamming units to both sides of your city.

The game tries to offer tactical aspects of various support characters, abilities and attack modes, but in typical tower defense style, once the enemy arrives it's just a hail of hitpoints being lost on both sides. It's hard to notice if you're losing any units and once the enemy breaks through first line of defense, it's usually game over.

Why a positive verdict? Because it's cute, it gave me four hours of solid fun and I think that's decent for the price paid. I will probably play a few more games eventually if mood strikes.

The game concept is nice, and it feels bad to not recommend it knowing how much content it has, and how polished it is.
Unfortunately, for me the game is not very enjoyable due to a few important parts, that I honestly have no idea why aren't they better.
It seems that the developers wanted very simple controls, so that the player could focus only on playing the cards. This is not a bad thing by itself, but it becomes so when the design behind what you cannot control is poor.
I just can't stand seeing ranged units in front of walls, so that if you don't send back each individually, they simply die extremely easily. Or being unable to deploy units in any way to defend your castle once the wall has been destroyed etc.

It seems little, but when you spend a long time in a run, and you lose all the progress because the game is not well done, and you cannot control things yourself to avoid it, it becomes frustrating and unfair.
I also believe the balancing leaves very much to be desired. Its unreasonable to be able to win the first run with the basic leader, with basically no idea of what to expect, nor how things work, but lose so many with new unlocked characters. They simply have some dependencies that if the run doesn't get running, gives you no chance at all.

This leads me to my last point. The rng.
I should say that it doesn't always have a big role, but it is again, with certain characters that have extremely tight dependencies with some resources, such as population, that the game may simply not allow you to play at all.
In my opinion, the player does not have enough resources to consistently get into the game, even if adapting its playstyle. This often happens with run-type games, but this one specially is severely damaged by it. In others, you feel weak and it is not very satisfying, but it only means that you'll need to try harder, but it still depends on you. In this game, precisely because you have so little control on the low level control, it feels that you are completely unable to play, only that you slowly suffocate until you eventually lose.
It's just that the amount of options the game gives you are not enough to prevent this. You have just a few chances to get useful cards, and if you don't, you'll likely never recoverd.

130225954.review:
It's unique and that's the main reason for my recommendation.

I rate it 7/10 (instead of 9/10) for awful high-end experience (60-120 waves) and chores for achievements.

[h1]Summary[/h1]
The goal in this one is to build a city and defend it. Kingdom games are the closest thing to this, but you build structures/spawn units using cards. This game is quick-paced, doesn't have as many resource management chores (compared to Kingdom) and I found it engaging.

There's lots of variety provided by 6 classes, but as is with most deckbuilders, there's not enough to make different runs with the same Leader/Class feel different. The reason for that is there are many cards giving the illusion of many options, but most options are useless even for basic victory.

[b]Not Tower Defense[/b]
The way to tower defense victory is pathing and using correct mix of AoE, Direct damage and CC. The way to Ratropolis (a DECKBUILDER) victory is building a kingdom (and slim deck) with many synergies with 1 or 2 things. 




[h1]Gameplay(8/10)[/h1]
Main thing this gameplay has over similar deckbuilders is it doesn't require many calculated/precise actions, which makes it quick-paced. It takes about 20min to learn the basics of each class and from that point I found myself quickly performing most actions on autopilot. It's a positive for me, because micro-managing every point of damage(common in deckbuilders) becomes tedious too fast.

Core systems (I recommend watching first 5 minutes of ANY video) to get 
[list]
[*] You start in a camp with main building and 2 walls. If main building takes a few hits - you lose.
[*] Use cards (and pay gold) to spawn troops, build buildings (buildingss once per card), activate temporary buffs and such.
[*] Build walls to get more territory to build in (and fall back to, if outer most walls falls).
[/list]

[b]Classes/Leaders[/b]
There are 6 "Leaders" to play with and they play drastically differently. Also each leader has male/female versions, which have different starting kits (sufficiently different).

For example (overview for few classes, I suggest going in blind):
[spoiler][list]
[*]General is more classical troop/army-focused class. Male and female are only marginally different.
[*]Merchants get access to mercenaries (temporary troops), and some tools that scale with amount of gold you have or Taxes(passive income). Male has access to infinite gold and female does not, which leads to completely different playstyles, while cards are mostly the same.
[*]Builders get access to ways to build, move/remove, upgrade and protect buildings. The deck consists of defensive structures (like fire towers, trebuchets, traps, etc) and structure manipulation tools. These can beat the game in tower-defense style, without using troops much.
[/list][/spoiler]

[b]Biomes[/b]
As you start the game, you pick a biome to build your settlement in. With this you choose 2 things: enemy types (their strengths or your own problems), bonus you're getting after waves (building upgrade, troop defense or card cost reduction cards). Different biomes can be better or worse with specific leaders/playstyles

[h1]Negatives[/h1]
[list]
[*] "Progression". You get XP for leader you play as, which unlocks cards/relics to find in future runs. I don't like this type of progression in general (it's just a push to grind), and this game doesn't make it very exciting as most unlocks are boring. If nothing else, I'm thinking of the drop pool gets diluted by useless options.
[*]Can feel unfair / poorly balanced at higher wave count.
  [list]
     [*] Most cards are useless. For instance this game features status combo mechanics, which are difficult to execute and don't scale at all. 
     [*] Very few tools/combos are capable of scaling with enemies when going for high wave count. Around wave 50 even basic enemies wipe out strongest defenses unless you have a specialized build. Some bosses are difficult to kill even around 30th wave as their HP is crazy high. 
     [*] Around wave 60 (earlier on some biomes) walls become useless as enemies are capable of tearing them down in about 3 seconds.
     [*] Some enemies bypass walls and disable your buildings (essentially disabling your ability to defend or deal damage). You can fix them, but it feels like a chore. Those enemies ALSO have crazy HP at higher waves, so it's not easy to get rid of them.
     [*] All ways to victory at high level are through cheesy infinite scaling and not strategy.
[/list]
[*] Sound needs some tuning. It's very loud by default and when there are multiple enemies attacking something, it's just annoying to listen to.
[*] Poor resolution support.
[*] Bugs/Crashes. I only had problems on 1 run, but it was my longest run (trying for 120 waves) with crazy amount of bugs. I had to save scum like crazy to work around those bugs and complete the run. 
   [list]
      [*] One event kept crashing the game consistently, when I tried to trigger it. I don't know what it was, I had to skip it.
      [*] Later the game crashed as it couldn't handle many crabs attacking buildings. It took me a while to figure out and even longer to work around. I had to save-scum to let those buildings die BEFORE too many crabs spawn. 
      [*] The game then proceeded to spam with null pointer exceptions (still about Crabs), until the very end of the run. Thankfully it was text and did not crash the game.
      [*] At some point I lost all my troops because they decided to move out of OP turret range. That is bad because the turret can kill and troops only defended walls that die in seconds. Another savescum restart.
      [*] As a cherry on top, after every crash I had to reset resolution, because the game does not support ultra-wide and on restart it gets all stretched.
[/list]
[/list]

For what it's worth, I reported the biggest bug and devs started looking into it within like an hour of me posting it and replied asking for logs in 7 more. I often report and check other people's reports on games I find problems with. It's very rare for devs to respond at all regarding a released game. I respect their diligence.


[h1]Achievements(5/10)[/h1]
Many of them are generic chores, that pretty much just pad the game.
[list]
[*] Beat Pollution 20 (equivalent to Slay the Spire ascension)
[*] Beat a game with every class in every biome
[*] Beat a game under specific conditions (like without using non-melee units; without upgrading cards; without going over 1000 gold; without getting relics)
[*] RNG achievements (get 3 specific relics; get 10 relics in 1 run, etc)
[/list]
Very few of these are challenging, but many of them require a dedicated run (or in case of RNG many attempts).

More of a 'meh' than a 'no'.
Ultimately I've enjoyed most of my time with it, but I'm over it.

In terms of random bullshit (like Hearthstone) it's pretty good actually, there are plenty of random effects but most of them are manageable or mitigated in some way.
One of the character's powers for example is "choose one of X random skill cards", but the fact that you can scale up the number of choices means that you have a degree of control over it.
Another power is "discard X cards and replace them with temporary cards", but the cards you get are buildings which are a permanent structure; so outside of getting exactly the right card it's not terribly important if you get generally good or bad picks, as you're not going to place most of them (due to having limited space to place buildings).

One of the biggest flaws is that of scaling difficulty, due to it being a 2d plane enemies 'stack up' quite dramatically; you generally either need to railroad the combat system or overwhelm the enemies later on in order to win fights later in the game.
Enemy stats also scale quite high, which leaves some cards with 'flat' damage quite underwhelming toward the end; one character class in particular seems to suffer from this quite badly as one of their big effects is a flat damage over time.
This is mostly not an issue if you end the game at the 'end', but if you go beyond wave 30 into endless mode, MOST things wind up being worthless which is pretty sad; you NEED to railroad mechanics, or use specific combos to make horrendously powerful units if you want to have any chance of surviving. I haven't unlocked all the cards but I think your endless mode options are pretty few, which in a deck builder is pretty lame.

Probably the worst aspect is the user interface though; it's not good at all.
You can push-pause the game, but you can't interact with most elements while paused, or even examine your cards; tooltips will only appear if you mouse over something while unpaused, and then you can pause to read it, the same is true of cards 'popping up' so you can read their text.
Moving units can be done in one of three ways; move all units from one wall to the next wall left/right, move all units from one wall to a targeted wall, or move one specific unit (which you can't select while paused and are usually moving around and stacking up with one another making it hard to click exactly the one you want) to the next wall left/right. This makes moving your army around a huge pain in the ass.
There's a lot of little annoyances with it that are hard to remember and describe, but the UI is just very unpolished suffice to say.

TL,DR: Overall I mostly like the game, but it has some serious flaws. If you like these sort of games you'll probably have a good time for quite a while, but it won't take long for the novelty to wear off.
Also documentation (in game and out of game) is very poor; there's no event log in game, military cards have some 'hidden' stats (movement speed, attack range, etc.), I'm pretty sure one card has a straight up unmentioned mechanic because something weird was happening with it that I couldn't otherwise explain, and wiki / guides are very incomplete and outdated.
ALSO also, why are the mutant rats that caused the apocalypse, and the only presented story of the game, the least of your worries? That's pretty weird.

117502670.review:
[h1]  🐭  Ratrópolis  🐭 [/h1]

Ratrópolis es un título que, como amante de los juegos de cartas, me atrajo inmediatamente cuando hace meses, lo descubrí en la tienda de Steam.

Fue a primeros de año cuando lo encontré en oferta (7,49€, la misma cantidad que se pide en las actuales ofertas veraniegas) y lo compré, sin tener en mente una fecha concreta para jugarlo.

Era de suponer que Ratrópolis sería un juego que sin duda, me divertiría, y por ende, me llevaría un buen puñado de horas para completarlo. Había que encontrar un hueco en el que disfrutarlo jugándolo de seguido.

Siempre tengo en mente a Slay the Spire cuando compro un juego de cartas. Como referente del género, espero que los nuevos juegos que adquiero se parezcan en cuanto a esa experiencia de vicio insano que te impide dejar el juego hasta que lo completes, perdiendo las nociones básicas sobre espacio y tiempo en el trayecto.

He de decir que cuando inicié Ratrópolis y le dediqué las primeras horas, no me daba la sensación de que este juego fuera a cumplir con la anterior promisa.

Y es que, tomando como referencia a StS (Slay the Spire), a primera vista, son juegos muy distintos.

 🐀En primer lugar, porque Ratrópolis es un juego de defensa de torres. Es decir, nuestra misión no es ir avanzando por un mapeado aleatorio e ir derrotando enemigos y jefes, no. Aquí hemos de sobrevivir con éxito ante oleadas de enemigos que quieren atacar y destruir nuestra ciudadela habitada por simpáticos y afables roedores. Para ello, utilizaremos una serie de cartas de distinta tipología.

Podremos construir edificios, colocar combatientes ratas y lanzar poderosas habilidades. Todo esto, mediante un coste económico (no, aquí no hay maná) y un coste en personal rateril. Como es lógico, siempre comenzaremos con una "baraja", que podremos ir ampliando mediante eventos, tesoros que surgen tras derrotar oleadas, y en el mercader, que de vez en cuando, se dejará ver, montando su pollino, en el centro de la ciudad.

Un concepto sencillo, pero que esconde una dificultad de ejecución exitosa tan alta que cada partida se convertirá en un auténtico reto.

Con estos mimbres, no parece a priori un juego parecido a StS, pero con el paso de las primeras partidas podremos observar similitudes con la obra maestra referente en el sector.

Y es que pronto descubriremos que podemos utilizar 6 personajes, cada uno con sus cartas típicas y sus "barajas". El mercader inicial dará paso al general, al ingeniero, al científico, al chamán y al navegante.

Cada uno posee unas mecánicas únicas que al ir descubriéndolas, el jugador quedará cada vez más prendado con el sistema de juego y querrá experimentar con las decenas de opciones que surgen tras cada construcción.

También tenemos la opción de contratar consejeros. Estas egregias ratas nos otorgarán poderosos beneficios. ¿Puede sorprendernos que 3 de los 4 personajes de StS sean "consejeros" de Ratrópolis? Uno de los múltiples guiños que el juego se guarda bajo la manga.

Los modos de juego son sencillos: 3 biomas distintos, con opción de elegir al comienzo de la partida.

Para superar una partida, hemos de sobrevivir 30 hordas. Si queremos desbloquear los logros, esto se multiplicará otras 3 veces, para tener que superar 60, 90 y 120 hordas. Serán partidas intensas, y que necesitarán la precisión cirujana: un solo error lo mandará todo al traste.

Como en StS, cuando acabamos con éxito la partida, podremos subir el nivel de "polución" hasta 20, donde irá aumentando la dificultad.



Con todo esto, y sobre todo gracias a su propia impronta, Ratrópolis se convierte en un juego que, probablemente, te acabe viciando hasta el mismo nivel que StS. Acabarás dando vueltas, una y otra vez, se convertirá en ese reto que te autoobligas a superar y que no pararás hasta lograrlo. Y esto merece los 7,49€ que piden en oferta por él, incluso los 15€ sin oferta no serían una locura. Digno de mención es que el juego está disponible en Android (se vende en la PlayStore de Google) , y que es totalmente compatible con SteamDeck, donde un servidor ha terminado un par de partidas.

Porque a fin de cuentas, el que suscribe lo ha completado en 100 horas repartidas en 2 semanas de juego. Ha cumplido con creces lo que esperaba cuando lo adquirí.

Por tanto, es un juego que sin duda alguna recomendaría a cualquier jugador que haya disfrutado de StS, o de cualquier otro roguelike de construcción de barajas, o en general, de cualquier juego de cartas.

TL:DR; A mix between deck building and strategy, Ratropolis has a rather steep learning curve but the difficulty falls off once you've learned each faction leader's winning combination. Casual gamers will be turned off by the challenge of jugging both aspects of the game, but there is an appeal to gamers who enjoy a face-paced cerebral game.

--------

What do you get when you mix Slay the Spire and Kingdom? You get Ratropolis, whose cutesy facade which conceals a challenging deck-building strategy game.

Kind of.

...Wait, you haven't heard of Kingdom (2015)? Kingdom: New Lands? Kingdom: Two Crowns? No? Tsk, tough crowd. 

Anyway. Both aspects of the two married genres are important. You'll need to master both: 
1) The strategy layer (economy, population, armies, a bit of positioning) 
2) The deck building (combos, scaling to late game)

Each (successful) run takes about an hour. 

In spite of this game originally being a mobile game, this isn't really a casual game. While the early waves in each run start easy, less prepared gamers may quickly be dismayed as the enemies scale incredibly high by the late game. Mastery of each leader's main combo is essential to win.

That however is also the game's main flaw, in my opinion. There are main combos using basic cards for each leader which are totally necessary to win.
Examples:
1) The merchant leader's main tactic is to fuel his economy with labor combos then buy stupendous number of mercenaries.
2) The general leader's main tactic is to grow his troops with a steady supply of experience, and so his main tactic is summoning extra enemies and earning extra bounties from each enemy.
3) The shaman's main tactic is to sacrifice lots of throwaway troops for money and power, then quickly refill her ranks with graveyards.
4) We don't talk about the Navigator.

The issue is that there is just one general main tactic for each leader. Once you've figured out how to run the main tactic for each leader, the difficulty curve drops like a rock. It's a "right, that's what I was supposed to do with this leader" feeling. Kind of like Kingdom, really.

Certainly a game worth trying out. Just, take a moment to overview the glossary so that you know how cards are meant to combo together when you find you are stuck.

Squeek.

104825511.review:
[b]Ratropolis Review
Purchase Price: $14.39 (-20%)
Regular Price: $17.99
Play Time: 30-45 minutes for first 30 waves
100% Completion: No (78% of the way there!)[/b]

tl;dr - Ratropolis is a unique blend of deck-builder and tower defense with an adorable artstyle that has become one of my go-to “I don’t know what I want to play” games.

Ratropolis immediately captivated me with it’s artstyle. It’s unique blend of deck-builder and tower defense has kept me coming back for more. The game is straight-forward & easy to learn, yet difficult to master. UI is intuitive and provides all relevant information to the player. Animations and SFX are very well done, and excellently supports the artstyle. 
There is meta-progression by earning xp as each of the six leaders in order to unlock more cards. In addition, after one has beaten the game once, pollution is unlocked where each subsequent victory will add an additional modifier making the game more difficult (ala [i]Monster Train[/i]). There is also a feature that allows one to continue playing after having beaten the first 30 waves as a new leader which triggers again after each additional 30 waves survived (the leader choices are random, no additional xp will be earned, however).

Although the re-draw timer has been brought up by some as a negative, it truly does add an entirely different dimension to the game, and I believe that it is a generally positive addition to the game. In most deck-builders (e.g., [i]Monster Train[/i], [i]Slay the Spire[/i], [i]Guild of Dungeoneering[/i], etc.), one needs to be certain that they are making the best play, and a timer simply does not belong. However, in a tower defense, time is just as much a currency as gold. Having a re-draw timer applies pressure, and instills a sense of impending doom - which I believe adds to the immersion in this post-apocalyptic world our little anthropomorphic rats must survive within. The hordes are drawing nearer by the minute, and the ratizens must rush to the defense of our city!

My main gripes with the game are the initial difficulty curve, the lack of maps (there are only 3), and the tediousness of achievement earning. Firstly, it seems that an early victory is extremely difficult without unlocking certain cards for each leader. Although, some leaders are easier than others (The General should have been the first unlocked leader, not the Merchant). Secondly, a campaign would be a very welcome addition to the game, and would easily allow the developers to add in a few more maps. Lastly, some achievements are simply a slog (survive the 120th wave), irritating as all hell because of uncontrollable factors (achieve victory while never exceeding 999 gold) or are RNG based (have x, y, & z advisor). 

Other than those minor criticisms & quibbles, I truly enjoy the game, and wholeheartedly recommend it.

The game is a fun concept, but as some other reviewers have stated it feels extremely unbalanced (particularly late game).  Some of the factions feel unwinnable even on the default land (Forest) and 0 pollution, as the difficulty in later waves scales up ridiculously.

I do enjoy the differences between each of the leaders, though some are way more challenging to figure out.  For example, I found the General to be the easiest, and the Builder is easy in concept (though I've yet to actually win with him).  On the other hand, the Scientist baffles me as he has multiple cards that rely on or manipulate *other* cards.  I found it too much to keep track of and figure out on top of real-time enemy waves.

I think some of the issues come down to having to work around multiple limitations:  having enough gold, having enough population, and getting the card(s) you need when you need them.  Combine that with the sharp jump in difficulty for later waves, and it starts feeling like you never have enough resources to actually win (regardless of how well you *think* you're doing in a given run).

94123988.review:
This is the sort of game that has me wishing Steam had a neutral review option. I had a good bit of fun trying out Ratropolis, however it's unlikely that I will play many more than the ~7.5 hours I've played as of posting this review. 

First things first, Ratropolis is a unique combination of several different genres. Coming straight off of Slay the Spire and Monster Train (two deck-building roguelites, for those unaware), I was intrigued to play 'A fusion of roguelite, tower defense, city-building, and deck-building!' Those [i]are[/i] all accurate descriptors, and I think the [i]idea[/i] behind Ratropolis is truly solid. For me, however, the fun ends only shortly past the novelty of such different genres being combined. 

The biggest problem I have with Ratropolis is its timer. This is of course necessary to allow for the tower defense elements (which run in real-time) to be able to function. Unfortunately, however, this means that the speed with which you play your cards is a legitimate factor for how well you do in the game. While most other card games (at least the ones that I've played) reward you for playing the correct cards in the correct order, Ratropolis doesn't really function in that way. In order to get a new hand, you have three options: wait out the timer, pay gold (one of your important resources), OR find a way to go infinite and bypass the timer entirely. Let's quickly go through each of these options.

1. Wait out the timer -- This comes with some obvious downsides. Any time spent waiting is time you're not playing cards, meaning you're missing out on possible gold, citizen, and unit generation. This is obviously not ideal.

2. Pay gold -- This option is fine early game, when the cost to reload your hand is <50 gold, and you aren't spending your gold on a lot, however the amount of gold it costs increases with every wave and quickly becomes hard to keep up with. Generating several hundred gold [i]per hand, every hand[/i] seems like quite a feat, especially since in the later parts of the game you'll likely be spending a lot of gold to get units down constantly. I don't see this as a viable long-term strategy, however it's possible there are legitimate ways to do this that I'm overlooking.

3. Go infinite -- The final option, and the one that really ruins the game for me. Thin your deck to ~5-7 cards and find a combination that allows you to generate money, then redraw the money generation card + the card you played to draw in the first place. The animation time of playing / drawing cards becomes a legitimate factor, so you really do want to narrow your combo down to the fewest cards possible. Unfortunately, this option seems to me to be the only viable strategy that allows you to keep up with the ever-increasing difficulty of the enemy waves. 

Going infinite is, in my mind, the absolute last solution a deck-building game should encourage, as it removes the thoughtful planning of turns and limits you instead to mindlessly playing the same couple cards over and over and over. On top of this, I think it's particularly silly when a game's goal is to side-step game mechanics. 

[b][REVIEW FINISHED][/b]
What follows are a couple possible solutions to the problem that may be worth exploring for future games that attempt this theme. 

1. Remove the timer entirely, and instead place a limit on the number of turns that can be played between waves. This would, of course, require cards and buildings to be designed with this system in mind. The way you play cards [i]during[/i] waves would have to be overhauled as well; maybe you would be unable to play cards during waves, or you could have a separate battles-only deck that [i]does[/i] rely on a timer between getting new hands -- I don't know. This solution would (ideally) remove speed as a factor, and encourage a more 'traditional' style deck-building play, where you carefully plan the optimal route for a given turn. 

2. Remove, or at least heavily discourage the possibility to go infinite. At the very least, this means removing the ability for cards to draw themselves (as in, a 'draw two' card adding itself back to your hand if you have only one card in your discard pile). This would likely require some work done to balancing the amount of cards drawn from card effects, as well as the amount of money you can generate in a turn, and the cost of performing actions like redrawing and playing units. In essence, rather than sidestepping the mechanic of paying to redraw, this system would encourage you to find ways to [i]overcome[/i] it.

Games with card mechanics tend to bore me, largely because the most effective strategies are usually the most dull. 
 Generally you are encouraged to get an effective loop and then reduce the amount of cards you have to a bare minimum to make your loop effective and repeatable.  The downside of this is that the more interesting cards tend to be too hard to use in these loops and so generally get culled.  Sure you can try to use them, and you can get them to work but it just won't work as well as your tight 5-10 card loop.

Ratropolis really isn't any different in this regard.  What makes it stand out a little bit more is the other factors of the game that make it an interesting package.  i.e. the economic, town building and tower defence elements.  These make it interesting enough to push past the generally negative aspect of card based games.

The biggest negatives is the RNG.  I'm generally not that opposed to RNG as a mechanic in games.  I find it amusing how plenty of people won't play games that use percentages, such as the Xcom games because they can miss with a 95% chance to hit (lol).  The RNG in this game is next level.  From the direction the enemies come from, the enemy types, the strength of the waves, the availability of cards from vendors or building, the actions you can take at the end of each wave, the advisors you get to choose, etc, etc.  If you hate RNG, don't play this game!!

Other than that it's a good little time waster.

More complicated but also vital:

Unlike many rogue-likes a single play through can seemingly go on forever (wave 30 is the normal 'end', it at least goes to wave 120- to the point where the game was struggling to keep up with the units on screen). The flavour and the theme of the game are interesting enough, the events and waves (of enemies) have enough variability where you are kept interested, but theres not too many that it seems impossible to account for/remember. Since its single player balance isnt as big of an issue, though you will find certain classes are far harder to win with than others, you will find some very strong mechanics (to name a few: minus armor stacking, stalling waves with baths and using cards like breed) but it is fun to build towards combinations that are very strong, and you will need to have done this to beat waves past 30- especially 100+- and high pollution runs. The difficulty scales well with pollution (equivalent to ascension(STS)/covenant (Monstertrain). There is enough content to keep you busy for a long while with 6 classes, with 3 different areas, and too many cards to count, however it does need to capture your attention first and foremost.  The difficulty on high pollution teeters with "too difficult" as it requires luck to consistently beat- earthqaukes, plague rats aren't the run killers, its not getting key cards (notably cards that increase your population like, breed, warren (for scaling), even cards like houses and apartments for early game defense) that will make you lose. Of course its a choice to play on high difficulty and with more balance I suspect it will become challenging and skill based enough to win without having everything out of your control go right. Overall this game is really fun, especially if you like making the best decisions quickly, its like many other rouge like card games with the fast paced gameplay of an RTS, and it does well to combine both of the genres.

86427986.review:
The balance of this game is way off. As other's have said, there seems to be a huge difficulty spike right around wave 25. Enemies go from not being able to touch your walls, to mowing everything down in their path. There's also the issue with card balance. At the beginning of every game you get a few Cheese cards. Cheese cards give you 30 gold, plus an additional 30 for each Cheese you have in your hand. The issue is that they cost 40 gold. This means that you have to draw two Cheese cards to get any benefit from them, and this becomes harder and harder to do as you start adding cards to your deck. The risk/reward here is off. Cheese cards go from mildly useful at wave one, to be obnoxious unplayable garbage within just a wave or two. Just why? There's already a timer/cost to drawing cards; there just doesn't need to be this extra risk/cost. A lot of cards are this way, just entirely too situational to have in your deck.

And this unbalance continues to other aspects of the game. Ranged units can, and do, miss. Frontline units will often run out to engage the enemy, which will sometimes be outside the range of the ranged units fire. Units gain EXP and level, but are hard to keep alive. Once you start losing units, you're basically done for as any new unit you plop down will be weaker than the veteran unit that just died. Moving units is incredibly difficult- you either move everyone as a mob or click individual ones and hope that the command to move them pops up. Either way, micro-managing is next to impossible.

If the game were $5, I would say, sure, give it a go. But, at $18, it's a hard no.

85597944.review:
I'm not usually into the deckbuilder kind of games because most of them don't allow you to have much fun outside of min-maxing.
I still try a few every now and then because there are some really good games in it that are well worth playing.

This one happens to be one of those.
If you don't find a snowball strategy you will probably lose, but that's also fine since you can experiment with various combos without much pressure and you still unlock things at a slower rate.

Each of the 6 classes play quite differently, with quite a few cards that are unique to them.
For example, the merchant focuses on making tons of gold and a lot of his military cards only require gold but only stay for a period of time instead of taking population, so one of the strategies is to get cards that increase that timer in order to let them stay a lot longer while making a ton of gold with "labour" cards that temporarily use your population.
The military class on the other hand has cards that can "rank up" as when they get enough exp from killing enemies, resulting into some quite powerful units if you can keep the basic ones alive for long enough (and use special buildings to help the exp).
The builder has overall weaker military units but can get really crazy with buildings.
The other 3 classes are a bit harder to grasp at first but all of them has quite a lot of potential if played properly.

Unlike most deckbuilding games you are not limited by your deck size and your max hand size is pretty substancial so both small decks and large ones have their advantages, making it significantly easier to get into and get hooked.

There are 3 environments that each have a special bonus you can get from clearing waves as well as their own enemies that can require a bit of thought to handle properly (like the coast where some enemies are sent directly over the wall, potentially wreaking your ranged units if they are not tough enough).


That being said, there is at least one big bad point in the fact that you can't save at all, so given that a run takes around an hour at least (and potentially much more if you go beyond wave 30) it's not the game that you can fire, play a few waves for a few minutes and come back later.

A pretty flawless game in terms of execution, Ratropolis is a game where I have difficulty telling if things I find frustrating are intentional design features to increase difficulty, which is always a good sign. Although it has rather a bit of RNG, when I lose (and I lose fairly often), I can nearly always find the mistakes I made in hindsight.

The core gameplay is a mashup of deckbuilding, tower defense, and even Starcraft (the devs appear to be Korean), and shows a very very deep understanding of game design - everything you do in this game has an opportunity cost and may come back to bite you in the back later. Hire a low-powered unit just to survive? You may have trouble getting rid of it later for better units. Build a building to help economy early on? Better hope you get a Demolition card in the future or it's a permanent space hog in your city which may force you to expand. 

Since you can't predict the future in the game, in the early game, it's common to bounce from tactic to tactic before you can develop a coherent long-term strategy. The core of the game is speed management and the ability to make good snap decisions, somewhat similar to speed chess but with far more emphasis on coping with random situations. I'm not joking when I say this game probably will help you develop and hone your analytical skills. The results of mismanagement are just like real life - they only rear their ugly heads fifteen or so minutes in the future and then you realise that failure is nigh-inevitable as it gets exponentially expensive (cycling your deck) just to survive. The early waves might seem dull and uneventful, but they actually do lay the groundwork for your long-term success.

The developers also understand that everything is a resource - they aren't just limited to gold and your little fuzzy Ratizens. Space is a resource. Time is very much a resource. Gold is a resource. Enemies are resources. In true Korean fashion, even APM is a resource - some actions clog up your mouse and attention and may deprive you of developing and paying attention to trends which need to be addressed before you realise you made a grave mistake 10 enemy waves later.

The gameplay is addictive. The art is cute, from the cartoony rat citizens to the helium-induced rat babbling. The difficulty is just spot-on. Every Rat Leader has significantly different playstyles, and perhaps a telling feature is that nearly 50% of the people who own this game have played more than 10 games. Best of all, the game is very reasonably priced. 

It's not often I find a game where I honestly have trouble coming up with valid criticism which isn't overly petty. I can't recommend this game hard enough - do yourself a favour and try it.

84668186.review:
So a note upfront to all you people looking for a Slay the spire/Monster train experience and/or are looking for a chill game where you can strategize and deliberate to come up with the perfect busted build: THIS IS NOT THAT KIND OF GAME

Ratropolis is a Roguelike/Deck building/STRATEGY game which leans heavily on the last part of that combination. Though fun, it's very active for newer players.
The game works as follows:
You start your game with 1 of 6 leaders that decide your active and passive abilities and those, in turn, decide the way you SHOULD play. You then pick a zone that decides which enemies show up and which boons are common to show up for winning battles. From there you're dropped into a sideview of your, soon to be, kingdom and are tasked with building up your settlement by hiring units, building structures and exacting actions; all picked from your deck. That deck can be added upon by buying cards from shopkeepers that show up and substracted upon by various ingame mechanics (like events, buildings that have that ability or boons). At certain time indices you will be raided by the enemy in a wave-like style. A total of 30 waves need to be beaten before you "win" after which you can choose to continue or end your run.
All the while you need to juggle available population, money and structure abilities
If you win (or get rekted) you then accumulate experience which opens up new cards and/or advisors (this game's version of relics).

Sounds easy enough if not that time won't wait on you to make the choices; the next wave WILL come, treasure chests you didn't pick up WILL despawn and the merchant WILL leave and that's not even mentioning the idea that the game has a measure of RNG like any good roguelike has. You might not get the cards you need at that time in hand, or in the shop or maybe not in the combinations you want. This CAN put people off in extreme fashion....you might be fine from wave 1 to 10 only to suffer from bad rng and die by attrition....you might get horribly murdered in under 10 waves even.

Does this mean the game isn't any fun? Funnily enough; quite the opposite if you're anything like me. The progression from every loss is still progression and when you do win that first time it does feel like a true win, hard earnt and bloodsoaked.
However, as my very top line said, it's not a game for people who're looking for a chill game to play whilst also doing something else; Ratropolis demands your full attention.

As for the rest:
The music per zone is chill and relaxing to listen to but nothing truly exceptional....not that you would have time to notice anyways.
The graphics are cute; you're playing a nation of rats after all and seeing those rodents dressed up in various armor and wielding a variety of weapons does give each unit type their own feel....a paltry cityguard truly looks like a poor man's shieldbearer and seeing an exile swipe at enemies using their katana definitely gives each unit type its own style.
Gameplay wise it's a bit janky at times.Units don't occupy space and it can become hard (if not impossible) to target any individual unit (be they friend or foe) which often made me question why single target abilities even exist in the first place. Sure, big enemies are easily singled out and often do the most damage but if you're trying to target the healer in a throng of lizardmen... well.... good luck is all I have to say. In turn this leads to a line of thinking that AoE is vastly favoured over single target abilities but ALSO to situations where you get hopelessly steamrolled because that shaman who's keeping the enemy group up in health is the last to fall (ofc). Buildings you build are permanent unless you can get your hands on a very specific "spell" and buildingspace is limited at all times so you better be sure if you need that second copy of a building you already have because, once placed, it's usually there to stay until the end of the run.
The difficulty curve is another thing worth mentioning. Every 5 waves you get a champion, every 10 a miniboss and finally on wave 30 the actual boss. More often than not you can truly notice the spike in those segments and either you keep up.... or lose; simple as that. This also means that if you're stuggling with wave 6 then you prolly won't last untill wave 10 unless you TRULY shape up and make drastic decisions. It's something that disappointed me a bit; there's no clutch ....once your walls start falling it's usually over...buildings are paperthin and often don't allow you time enough to mount any sort of resurgence. Even your palace will fall to (what seems like) maybe 1 or 2 hits of even the weakest monster, let alone that group of 10 who just tore down that final wall.
In addition to that the game has some tricky mechanics and synergies that are not apparent like in Slay the Spire or Monster Train. A good example is how you starts with the Cheese-card which nets you 30 gold for each Cheese card in hand... but it COSTS 40 gold to cast one so it's only a net gain if you have at least 1 OTHER in hand or you might spiral into a deficit. Labor cards not ONLY cost gold and a ceratin amount of time to complete ALSO cost available population; which you then can't use to hire units....or vice versa; you might overdraft and realize you don't have enough free population to do any labour. There's no active pause in this game....time moves on and that usually means you don't have the time to carefully read the effects of new cards or think about what casting them entails; you HAVE to know. All of this makes the game quite difficult for a new player and as a result you'll often lose because of one of these unforseen side-effects.

All in all Ratropolis is a great game for new people who seek a challenge in the "coolness under fire" department and for experienced players due to the RNG but if you're looking for something to play whilst also watching a movie then I would stay far FAR away.

7/10

The game has come a long ways since the start of Early Access. I will try to keep it kind of short. Very much a fun game. But, can be quite difficult on new players! 

Pros: 
+ The cutest deck-builder on Steam. Easily! I'm not really a fan of rats/mice. But, the card art is so cute in this game that it just makes you happier seeing it. The voice acting is also so extra super well done and cute. 
+ Neat "lore" in a deck-builder. This isn't really a lore heavy/building game. But, what it does have is at least worth reading in my opinion. The very cute exterior hides a much darker interior. The random events are sometimes very brutal in the story they tell. Even the opening cinematic is pretty dark. 
+ Very quick gameplay. This can be seen as a con at times, though. While the early-game is a bit slow by design (not really in a bad way), the late game will be quite hectic. This is the only deck builder I've played where using the hotkeys is greatly recommended else you could fall behind. 
+ Fun mechanics. You have Skill cards that let you activate its effect when used. Building cards that you play once to place a build within your walls for a lasting effect. Advisers that can offer many different benefits. Various different mechanics on the military unit cards. It's not an exceptionally deep game. But, you can still create fun synergies and alter the way you play with them. 
+ Diverse Leaders. There are six rats that lead and each one plays differently from the others. They're not slight differences, either. The Merchant Leader can turn your economy into your best offensive option while the Shaman leader is wittling down the enemy with Curses. This becomes even more true as you unlock cards. 
+ Build Variety. While you don't generally "specialize" in certain themes like say a poison-based Silent in Slay the Spire, you can build thematically and create wombo combos with smart planning. Such as getting the Gladiator card from the Military Leader that increases the gladiator's max HP each time he is healed. Then, you get several methods of healing (buildings, advisors, skills) and you can rapidly make a tanky rat. Or, getting a lot of Curse cards as the Shaman to quickly stack up high amounts of Curse to deal strong damage over time. 

Cons:
- The most notable issue that you'll see on the Discussions forums and subreddit are the difficulty spikes. They've made attempts at smoothing it out throughout development and have certainly made it better with time. But, there is still a very noticeable increase in difficulty in the early 20s in waves (games are won at wave 30). You can be completely fine and even thriving one wave and then literally the next wave just lost. As you become better at the game, this gets much easier to combat. It is a hill you have to climb and can be a bit brutal on new players. Worth the climb! 
- RNG heavy! Like any other deck builders. It does sometimes feel like the odds are stacked against you. While it isn't bad enough for me (is for some others) to put me off, there have been times when you just get constantly bombarded with negative events and poor choices. Combine that with the noted difficult spikes, and it can lead to a very rough time. I consider this kind of a Pro as well. 
- There are a couple of relatively minor issues that I have problems with. Such as targetting with certain cards (Static) and there are times when I wish I could set on-use building to be used automatically. Not a huge deal and something the Devs may be looking at anyways. 

I'm not saying this is going to dethrone games like Slay the Spire or Monster Train. But! This game is definitely worth playing if you're a fan of the deck building genre.

[h1] I made a longer, more in-depth video review here:
https://youtu.be/AswB-16f02c [/h1]

Ratropolis is a roguelite, deckbuilder, tower defense, city-building, real time strategy game. And that is a lot to say at once but thats truly what this game is. It manages to combine all these genres into one game that not only feels unique but also a ton of fun to play.

The game has so many cool little features and mechanics it would take forever to explain them all so I just want to highlight a couple awesome parts about the game. 

First of all I was really confused on how a roguelite deckbuilder could also be real time but it does something very clever. After a certain amount of time passes you can discard your hand and draw a new one. However if you don’t want to wait you can spend gold to immediately draw a new hand. So there is a good balance of sometimes waiting because you need the gold for other things and sometimes you can afford to keep going through your cards.

Another thing I really like about the game is how unique all the different characters in the game are. They all have not only their own starting decks and abilities but they also have their own unique cards you will find in game. So when you play as the alchemist a lot of the cards that you get as rewards and in the shop will be themed around your character which is really awesome.

Also all of the characters have their own progression where you unlock new advisors, new cards you can find in the game and more.

This makes the game feel completely different depending on who you are playing as and since there are 6 characters to play as you have 6 completely different ways to play the game.

And so the overall goal of the game is to survive 30 waves but let me just tell you the game is really hard. It’s one of those games that is going to take you several tries before you even beat it a first time and the runs last like 40ish minutes. Also it appears to have the ascension level thing most roguelites have nowadays to increase the difficulty once you beat the game so I could really see some people putting hundreds of hours into this game if it is a roguelite that speaks to you.

My biggest complaint with the game is how the micro management is handled. And big disclaimer I am terrible at micro in games. I hate most RTS games but this seemed like it wouldn’t be too bad to handle and its not for the most part though the game makes it really hard sometimes. Like as far as I know you can’t just mouse over all the ones you want and move them to a different wall. You can move each rat individually or have all the rats at one wall move to another wall.

And I am sure this is something I am just doing wrong especially since I am terrible at RTS games but it just seemed very clunky in my opinion.

So overall Ratropolis is an example of one of my absolute favorite things in gaming. A roguelite that incorporates other genres and this game combines so many genres yet it’s not clunky and weird it is very streamlined, not confusing at all, and just a ton of fun. 

If this game looks like the type of game you might enjoy I would highly recommend picking it up especially since there appears to be a crazy amount of replayability in the game from the different characters, to the unlocks, to the ascension levels, to also just learning how to not suck at the game haha.

84384259.review:
Where to begin with this lovely little masterpiece, tucked away, behind the big name companies, and games that are currently out there.

I will say I have a bit of a biased when it comes rodents as a whole, I love them a lot, so to be able to play a game centralized around them is sort of a dream come true. And in the line of it being rodents, you fight a lot of enemies that naturally hunt rodents. I won't spoil the enemies, but I will say that you will be fighting things bigger than your soldiers 99% of the time, and it's disconcerning.

The gameplay is perfect. A lot of games have tried to blend things in that just simply were jarring, strange, or not very fitting for the way the game is suppose to be played. This game dares to be different, and added a rouge-like death mechanic, cards that add units, buildings, money, and skills, tower defense, and finally, city building, city management mechanics that work in unison with the rest of the game. If you die, you lose everything, if you don't manage your "Ratizens", you won't have enough soldiers, and if you don't manage your units on the field, you'll be overwhelmed. It's easy to learn, but very hard to master, because it's also luck based.

Which furthers us to the next points: RNG and the Enemy. The RNG in this game isn't just which cards your draw next, it's which cards the Merchant shows up with, or which one you pick from the Chest menu, or which boss you're going to face. At first it doesn't seem like it's that bad, but if you're preparing for a boss who, say, is going to attack your buildings instead of your units, and you get one that attacks your units... Game over.

Which brings me to the Enemy. Like any tower defense, the first waves are typically simple, allowing you to build up, farm up, and so on. The next set of enemies is strong, but if you have a good military, you'll handle it just fine. The last set of enemies, I will warn you, is where the real game begins. A lot of HP, typically able to one-hit your units, and run faster than the previous sets. This game is mostly perfect, but it's one blaring flaw is these last enemies, where the scaling is downright unfair. You might win on your second attempt, because of the first leader you unlock, like I did, but then the more you play, the more you realize just how lucky you were that one time. 

Which would be fine, if there weren't other regions that made these final enemies stupidly broken. The desert makes every enemy stronger, and when you have these things that have a lot of HP already, it just feels like they get a buff to smoke you. If there was something I'd ask the developer to change, it'd be these guys. The game is fun to play until they show up, and ruin your setup. It becomes dumbed down to unit spamming and praying you can redraw enough to beat them out. Seriously, there is no strategy to them. You have to have a unit with a lot of damage and not melee, or a lot of HP to handle them, or you lose. This isn't a fun way to play.

The flaw is blaring, as I said, but the game is still worth picking up at any price. It's cute, it's fun, it has a lot of things to do, it's a very interesting, enjoyable concept, and it has a lot of love put into it. If these end-game enemies were fixed, and maybe add an additional leader skill to choose from at the start, (perhaps unlockable?) I'd definitely say it's the best game to come out thus far. 9/10, would squeak again.

I love the Kingdom games. Quite a bit. I've been very sad ever since they came out, to learn that there is nothing else really like them. I think the format has a lot of potential for a variety of different genres and the 'build wide, defend the edges' gameplay is inherently suitable for games.

However this game, Ratropolis, pulls off the game format very well. It almost feels like "well duh, of course this works" when you start figuring out how the game works and how to win, and you see it all come together so well.

I enjoy Slay the Spire and Monster Train, but find I don't have the motivation to grind for completion. This game is proving to be different. The combination of Kingdom-esque gameplay, roguelike deckbuilding (always a fun time), and action means that your attention is captured and then kept.

Of particular note for this game, is the fact that the leaders are complicated enough that it takes a few playthroughs to really see what they're trying to do and how the cards come together. I've found so far (maxed out Military, halfway done with Economic and Builder), is that you get an extremely different gampelay experience based on the leaders. I find most roguelikes are pretty same-y, but in this game the Leaders are different enough that you are genuinely making different and deliberate decisions about how to play. They're very different from each other and it's been quite fun so far.

If you like Slay The Spire, Monster Train, and other roguelike deckbuilders, and/or like the Kingdom games: definitely give this game a try.

Ratropolis' balance is a bit wonky.  Each run, it's either impossible to win or you end up ridiculously overpowered.   This is why there's a lot of controversy between players about whether or not the balance is broken: how can it be too hard if it's possible to end up too easy?

It's because the balance is all over the place.  Different decks are much easier to win with than others.  This generates a false impression that the game is easier or harder than it seems because you're playing a deck that is genuinely easier/harder to play.  

I initially refunded this game, but I changed my mind and decided to keep it instead.  I can forgive a wonky balance when there's this much creativity on display.

Since the decks are not actually in competition with each other, think of the wildly different balance between decks as increasing the diversity of the play experience.  Diversity is not so bad.

Would I recommend this? Eh, if it's on a good sale, sure. You could even justify the full price if this is the kind of game that you really, really like.

Do I recommend this game at its full price? Not really. While the mechanics have a solid foundation, and there's a lot of "content", it feels like this game that really likes trying to pad its run-time. I like the game, I do, and it is really fun for the first few hours with its unique mechanics. But there are some serious issues with it that hold me back from loving it to its full potential.

The reason why I feel this way is going to require a bit of math so, bear with me here, potential buyer.

There are 6 heroes you can play as. Each of them has 10+ levels of experience which. To gain levels, you have to play as that hero. In my experience, a full game will get you about a level. So, you're looking at about 60 games. A new level will get you something new to play with, though very minor - think of it like completing a run in The Binding of Isaac, and then unlocking a single item you might find during the run.

And then, there's pollution levels. If you beat a level, you unlock the ability to play that level again, on a harder difficulty. You have to beat the previous difficulty, before advancing to the next. There's 20 of these per level, and three levels in the game. You don't have to just play the same level 20 times, but play and WIN the same level 20 times, to 100% the level. Each new level gives an interesting change to the difficulty in fun ways, but... well, look, there's a problem to this system.

These rounds aren't fast. A WINNING round will set you back at least an hour. Playing with largely the same set of cards and only one or two new ones, plus a single new change to something about the enemies that make them slightly harder [spoiler](for example: on Pollution 1 in one of the levels, the enemies are no longer affected by status affects)[/spoiler], for an entire hour, isn't enjoyable. It feels grindy at best.

Do I think this game is good? Sure. But I also think that it's very flawed. It is amazing those first few hours, but its primary flaw becomes fast-apparent: it drip-feeds you new content way too slowly, making the game feel rather stale rather quickly. If you want to 100% this game, you'll have to sink bare minimum 80 hours into it, and I worry that the game would feel almost identical to when you started by the time you finish it.



Oh, also, as someone who really loves rats, it upsets me maybe more than it should that they put the word "Rat" all over this, but clearly everything in this game is a mouse. I know it's pedantic but, cmon guys. Rats have smaller ears, and longer tails. You made an entire game around the idea of rats, the least you could have done was research the difference between rats and mice, this is REALLY easy stuff. I understand that mice are cuter and more marketable but... why not just call it Mouseopolis or something like that, if you were going to very clearly make it filled with mice?

79776866.review:
[b]A difficult game hiding behind a cutesy art-style and a casual facade, attracting the wrong audience and not providing enough to keep hardcore players interested.[/b]

Cards are poorly designed, many being gimmicks that aren't worth the trouble to use. More are unlocked as you play, but are just as gimmicky and useless, cluttering the card pool. The cards that do work nearly trivialize the game, as the main threats are just massively produced stat-bloated enemies which lead to boring endgames.

UI is a mess, as military troops are a hassle to manage and there are notifications and alerts all over the screen, vying for player attention in too many directions and causing a stressful experience ([i]especially[/i] when there are enemies attacking).

Early-game turns into a rush to build economy by quickly buying extra cheap turns. But basic early-game cards can actively hurt a beginner player to use carelessly. In addition, you can upgrade cards as well, but this also makes them even more expensive to use while providing only meager benefits. All these factors make the game rather unintuitive and newbie-unfriendly.

As for Hardcore players, they have a leaderboard ...and that's it. Most of the game is just digging through the markets to get the right card combos/setup and steamrolling once you get them. There's an optional endless mode, but it merely drags the game out by randomly destroying your buildings and/or military until you lose or give up.

There's also this awkward period where enemies stomp through your city if they get past your last wall, leaving you unable to do anything but watch.

I can't recommend this at all. It's just not fun to play and it's poorly balanced. And sadly, I'm not very hopeful that it'll improve when it leaves early access next month either, as the devs continue to needlessly nerf things each update.

Quite a shame, really... the art truly is cute.

Ratropolis is a roguelite deckbuilder and tower-defense game.

There are six different classes. Every class has different cards. You start with basic cards and have to survive waves of enemies attacking your city. With cards, you can build different buildings which will give you bonuses, etc., units and buffs or debuffs. Enemies attack from two sides so it's important to defend both sides equally. You can move your units around but it takes time for them to move from one side to the other. 

Through your run, you can upgrade cards, remove them from your deck, or get new ones. You constantly change your deck to make the best out of it. Destroying enemies gives you cheese as well as some cards do or some buildings produce it. You need cheese to play cards, buy cards, etc. 
Each character has a special ability. It can be upgraded in a run and is on a cooldown once you use it.

Every class changes the strategy of a run. Different maps force you to change your strategy. Special happenings are different on each map and can make your run easier or harder. 

In this roguelite, you unlock new cards and classes with every run which makes future runs a bit easier. 

The game is well balanced, free of bugs, and addictive with lots of content. 
It's a must-have for every fan of roguelite deckbuilder. The tower-defense elements go well with it. It's one of the best early access games out there. It can be stressful in the later waves of enemies, but you'll constantly learn new strategies to make future runs less stressful. 

I highly recommend the game. It's well worth the asking price of around 13€/USD right now. This is your last chance to buy it before it leaves early access in December and gets more expensive. 79556467.review:
Call me a dues-paying member of 'The Cult of the New' when it comes to genre mash-ups like this.  I can't get enough of them.  When Slay the Spire came out and combined roguelites and deck-builders I was hooked for 100+ hours and even back in my pre-COVID table-top gathering days, deckbuilders (Dominion/Thunderstone) were my favorite.  The combination of control and RNG is so delicious and it's exciting to see all of the ways developers are using this in either quality design or just experimenting with a gimmick.  

Ratropolis is certainly a deck-builder + tower defense, not quite as sure about the roguelite or city-building elements.  You are the leader of a newly found city for your Ratizens.  These mice are your workers that you will assign defensive roles, stations or have them do other resource or support jobs.  Your workers assignments are a major part of the game but there are also autonomous defensive buildings and 'skill' cards to keep things interesting.  For an Early Access game, it is improving at an excellent rate with solid balancing updates coming (and more needed, but I have faith).  I love the variation between the Leaders, their special cards and abilities and how they all help you form a better overall play.  The game is unforgiving - very difficult (as good tower defenses should be) and it will take multiple plays for you to even get a decent grasp of what simple strategies are.  I was thrown off at first at the degree in which I was staring at the timer to tick down so that I could draw more... the 'time as a resource' is understandable in tower-defense but it wasn't until I played for awhile that I really appreciated it in a deck-builder (which I had always regulated to being only turn-based in my head).  Now I really like the tension that aspect brings. I completely get how a lot of gamers who are less interested in experimental Early Access/Indie games can get annoyed, but this has really captured by imagination currently.

If you love tower defense and/or deck-builders and don't mind some growing-pains in this experimental mash-up, then this may be a great game to try out (I was dubious, but patient and I fell pretty hard for this).  I look at Early Access Indie games with a lot of grace and care much more about gameplay and execution of a new idea more than nit-pickier things that can easily be fixed pre-release.  If your sensitive about the finishings, you may want to wait.  

I just reviewed this for my podcast RYSK: Roguelikes You Should Know which should drop at the end of November 2020.

TLDR The game doesn't follow along with tried and true successful gameloops from other games of the genre, leaving it as a mixed bag. Not something you want to invest a lot of time in and 100% complete. The best gameplay and combos are available from the start and everything that follows is jank cards/combos and hyperspecific playstyle cards.

Games a mixed bag. In the beginning, it's a lot of fun. Sooner or later you figure out the basic mechanics with each of the leaders and the game starts to become a bore.

Unfortunately all the card unlocks that take awhile to grind out are hyper specific. Instead of providing these hyper-specific cards at the beginning to teach players how it "wants" you to beat the waves, it gives you some of the best cards right off the bat. There's really not much point to grinding out all the leaders because the card drops are always worse/very specific and you don't feel like you're gaining anything.

If they would re-balance the cards and the distribution, this would be a slam dunk. 

The normal game loop for these types of games is given different leaders with very specific playstyles, and working out how to beat the challenges with the options provided. Even if you don't win, you're still gaining xp to unlock new cards which expands and improves upon the gameplay each leader offers. It would be really cool to grind different leaders up to unlock a larger pool of cards. 

Your first games will be the best and easiest, because none of the cards unlocked in the future are really good compared to what you already have. Military/builder/factory are so easy with just the base cards. There are so many heavy hitting cards, then you unlock random "cloak cards" or other dirt cards that don't even compare to the cards you start with. Ultimately you're weakening your total card pool filling it with dirt. 

Why would the players grind to unlock jank, when you have such bomb combinations to start with? All the critical pieces to have a successful run should be unlocked through different trees. It makes no sense.

Es un juego genérico que combina perfectamente Slay The Spire + Kingdom. 

¿Por qué? 

- De Slay The Spire: emplea un mismo sistema de cartas, con rotaciones y sinergias, con héroes propios (con set de cartas propias y arquetipos). 

- De Kingdom: tanto la visión (el plano) del juego como el mapa, es en 2D, y la cámara tienes que moverla de izquierda a derecha. Además de ser un Tower Defense. 

Luego en el apartado artístico, usan imágenes vectoriales, donde la propia animación es a través de nodos anclados y con movimiento gelatinosos (tipo flanes), el dibujo y colorido sencillos y básicos.

La música es básica, y muy repetitiva. 

¿Cual es la novedad del juego o qué es lo interesante?

Pues que aquí hay varios héroes o personajes con sus propias habilidades y su propio set de cartas, con sus propias mecánicas y efectos, pero con la particularidad de que puedes "manipular" la partida con las habilidades única del héroe, pues otorgan una cierta ventaja.

Existiendo además, eventos durante la partida, que condiciona para peor o para mejor, efecto alzar. 

Por otra parte, existe la aleatoriedad de las cartas, en la que puedes mezclarse con los de diferentes personajes, cosa que pasaba en Slay The Spire. Pero en general, es una combinación de dos conceptos: Slay The Spire + Kingdom Classic, muy acertada. 

En cuanto a la dificultad, es adaptable, de fácil a muy difícil, sin llegar a penalizar/obligar a jugar tal modo, sin que te condicione. 

Yo se lo recomiendo a tod@s que le guste mucho los Kingdom Classic (los juegos tipo Tower Defense), que a su vez, le gusten también crear set de cartas, para generar sinergias y combos.

Yo estoy encantadísimo, es muy adictivo, y se pasan las horas volando.

Todavía está en early access, pero por lo que ofrece hasta ahora y por el precio, es una buena compra recomendada.

73/100: Some days you're the rat, some days you're the trap. A pretty elegant combination of Slay The Spire-esque card game and base builder RTS. With a bit more pizzazz, a (much needed) permanent progression system, some QOL fixes and balancing and a big handful of calm-down pills, this could be a true rat-serpiece.

Full <Early Access> ratview and feedback below:

= Intro =

Had this on my list since forever. Wanted something different, so gave it a shot.

= Gameplay 61/00 = 

Whew. Where to even start on this one? And suddenly, I can't think of many good rat puns.

At it's core it's Slay the Spire, except that rather than using abilities, you build units and structures, expand your base and population limit and accelerate your economy.

So how does it feel? Honestly, it's like They Are Billions and Spire had a baby. And that baby was a rat. In 2D. 

At first, this seems quite twee and forgiving. However, within the chest of this rodent beats the heart of the villain from Saw. Beating 30 waves sounds fine, but boy - does this take a bit of doing. Even on the easiest difficulty, it feels like I'm only starting to get a handle on the game quite a few hours in.

There are a few reasons for this. The 'seams' that most other rogue-lite deckbuilders run on feel mostly absent here - the cards are quite straightforward and with the exception of the *very* rare opportunities to get advisers (essentially the artifacts of the game) lack any real interaction. 

On top of this, the game relies a lot on RNG, even more-so than similar titles. It's entirely possible to lose a game in the 20s simply because you didn't get the right draws on infrastructure or units. And similarly, the 'golden runs' - where you get some crazy synergy going feel few and far between. 

This may be because a lot of things that seem powerful (quest cards, some buildings) - the actual bonuses they offer are really small for the work/space they take. Static defenses are a good example of this, as they hog much needed real-estate and cannot be moved or even demolished without a specific, rather rare card.

My final issue gameplay wise is how frantic the game is. Especially later in the game, it feels like I'm running with infinite gold and population, but being held back at times simply because I don't have the APM to play the cards I want where I want (some are very fiddly), fire my static defenses (many are manual) handle structures that need clicks, cast spells and keep an eye on combat. Does a deckbuilder need to be this...panicky? 

Simply allowing orders to be given and buildings to be used during Pause would help this a lot.

A lot of rogue-lites counter the difficulty and RNG with some sort of permanent progression system, allowing repeated runs to grant permanent bonuses to a hero or player. I really, really like this sort of mechanic as it creates a constant feeling of small gains even if a run ends in catastrophe. However, aside from cursory card unlocks, the game has nothing like this and feels like it badly needs something like it, to alleviate the frustration.

None of this is to say that this is a bad game. It's not. Next to the really awesome Monster Train, this is likely my second favourite deckbuilder at present. So much potential

= Graphics and Audio: 55/100 = 

The graphics are actually quite nice. Strong, 2D visuals. The fact that the max resolution is only 1080p is a bit annoying, but will likely get sorted before release.

However the music will get on your nerves fast, as will the sounds of the rats. The next time I hear a 'GAGOOO' or a 'BLARG BLAAA!' I'm going to try to eat my own keyboard. I'd love to disable SFX, but unfortunately a lot of important cues are handled in audio. Rrgh.

= Style: 80/100 =

It's such an original concept and the bones of the thing are excellent. I really don't have much to complain about here, except for the stuff I've already said - it needs more 'seams' and some permanent progression.

= Value: 79/100 =

While a lot of the game feels slightly rough at this point, there is quite a lot to do at present. With 6 commanders, each offering a unique ability and some cool cards, 3 maps to conquer (and a random thing I've yet to try) and higher difficulties waiting to...well, test your luck against, there is a lot here for the price and it isn't even the finished product yet.

= Overall =

+ Excellent concept
+ Attractive visuals
+ Lots of cards
+ Challenging
+ Plenty of content for the price
+ Very active developers

- Crying out for some sort of permanent, incremental xp system/progression outside of a few card unlocks
- Audio can be annoying, but needs to be on
- Too fast paced for it's own good, especially later - needs to take a breath and let us do stuff while paused
- Many cards feel weak
- Lack of synergy between cards
- RNG can be frustrating, even for a deckbuilder
- Moving units around the base can be a chore
- Most defenses feel too pricey space wise to be worth it for their power, compared to raw pop/unit spam - and they all need to be automated.

Overall, I really like this game. That said, it's still got some rough edges that need sanding down. Definitely worth the price, if you enjoy this sort of game. Keep an eye on this one.
