This game is really close to being recommendable, but it's not quite there IMO.  There's a lot of neat concepts here, a real-time deck-builder provides for an interesting stress experience.  The sort of tower-defense play is neat as well.  But I think there's a balance that hasn't quite been struck and a few problematic mechanics.

One problem is the micromanagement of where units are.  It's just extremely tedious.  You can only place units on specific walls, to move them between walls requires multiple clicks (and moving just a few units is extremely complicated).  And so it becomes this game of maybe trying to just steadily recruit on the outer walls on each side and hope each side is well balanced?  If a strong wave comes from one side, don't even waste time trying to move the units to that side.  They'll be needed, but the experience of moving them over will be slow and frustrating.

Not to mention, never ever ever can you let enemies get further than your last wall.  Then you cannot build units on that side and cannot move units to that side (because there's no wall to move them to).  Which creates this odd 10s where you've essentially lost the second you lose an inner wall, despite the fact that you have gold to spare and units in your hand, and maybe even a dozen units on the opposite side just standing around pointlessly.

I think this game also has just a few too many mechanics trying to compete for attention at once.  The complexities of economy, buildings, units, unit position, and skills, and leader abilities, are all enough to make for a pretty solid deck builder.  When you add in a real-time element, it's a bit overwhelming.  And I say that as someone who 100%ed One Step From Eden, which is the most frantically stressful deckbuilder I had played until here.  But here it feels like a chore sometimes waiting for things to line up correctly.

I think this game has a future.  I would be happy to re-review later.  But for now, it's hard to keep playing.

This game is phenomenal!

To give a quick run-down of how this works: You are managing a settlement under siege. Every so often, waves of enemies will spawn to try and take down your city hall. In order to defend your settlement, you need to balance the various aspects of management with the help of a vast assortment of cards. You will need to make money, you will need to grow your population, you will need to expand, and you will need to recruit troops to defend your Ratropolis. 

There are six different leaders you can choose from, each of them focusing on a general aspect of the game. For example, the first leader you start with focuses on your economy, with cards tailored to making money faster. These different leaders provide different playstyles, although each can make use of cards of the others, provided they come across them.

There are also three different maps, with each map offering one unique faction of enemies (Enemies will be basic up until wave 10, then have the map-unique faction between 10 and 20) to further diversify runs.

And you might be thinking at this point "This sounds like a game I could sink a good number of hours in", and you'd be right.

You'd also be underestimating this game, because there's a button with a very modestly worded tooltip in character select: 'Leader Plus'.

"There may be differences from a normal game" is quite the understatement, because Leader Plus mode essentially overhauls a lot of the game, reworking some cards already present and fleshing out the decks of the three leaders that have Plus mode available right now. These new decks are more complex and make for a great challenge after you've gotten to grips with the other, base mode leaders.

Overall, Ratropolis is a uniquely inventive take on the roguelike deckbuilder genre, and manages to pull it off with style, while simultaneously heaping a boatload of content on you! Fair warning though: The game can be tough as nails, so if you want to learn the game, start off easy, and don't go to the coastal area!

71612573.review:
I got this game expecting something similar to Kingdom Two Crowns, given the visuals, and my final recommendation is geared around that. I'm also writing this review having put about 4 hours into the game.

I read some of the reviews that mentioned RNG early combos and difficulty spikes but thought this game would still be worth it. Turns out the game pacing is extremely fast. I've played on normal and hard and the longest any game lasted was 20 mins but that was one time I was really lucky. 
While working on unlocking certain leader cards (each leader has 3 sets of cards to unlock) and playing on hard. [u]Most of the time each game lasted 4 to 6 mins.[/u]
The roguelite aspect comes in with these card unlockables, similar to Slay the Spire. You receive XP at the end of each game. Playing on hard, I was getting about 100 xp per game and the first set of unlockables takes 300 xp (there are 6 leaders currently available).

On mechanics:
-The main mechanic/resource of the game is managing gold income you collect every 10-15 seconds. Building houses increases the income collected by 1 or 2. There are a 3-5 instant cards to collect gold early on (+10 gold per card in your hand, a cheese card: cost 40 to play and collect 30 gold for every cheese card in your hand, and farming: send two rat citizens to work on a farm... in 90 seconds collect X gold) and a couple of buildings that provide similar benefits. 
-The next most important resource is citizens, as you need available citizens to play troop cards. 
-The other major mechanic is deck building. A merchant will arrive occasionally selling 9 cards and every chest at wave end usually allows you to choose 1 of 3 cards.

In terms of genres does mixing resource management, base building and deck building in this case work? It's just a little fast for my taste and as other reviews mentioned RNG plays a huge role. Especially in getting access to crucial troop cards early on for surviving waves 5 and onward.

On game pacing there is hardly any time to catch your breath. After you defeat a wave a chest drops that will de-spawn after 15 secs that contains your reward for surviving. Certain buildings have abilities that trigger every 120 seconds that require you to click on an icon above the building to trigger. Add into this the fast pace card combo playing and you start to get the idea. The game is fun but there is no exploration involved / moving units outside of the fort walls. You expand your base simply to have more room to place more buildings. In terms of pacing / number of things to click on screen think mobile game. There is no safe daytime followed by nighttime attack cycle like on Kingdom Two Crowns and each game is designed to be very short.

So far there is one tower and one type of wall. All of your main defensive options come from unit cards that you unlock. I think I saw one building that will double the damage of your towers and a quest card that will give your walls extra hp. But the quest cards are usually pretty hard to fulfill. One gripe with quest cards are they take up room in your inventory and you draw them into your hand. I understand that once unlocked you can play them like regular cards but they don't feel worth it. Like the space they consume in my deck plus the low probability of fulfilling them each game just isn't worth it. 

A couple of other gripes. After either of the last walls closest to your fort collapse, it becomes impossible to place any more units on that side / send military units towards that side. Your main building despite looking like a castle has a barely any hp. Seriously if the enemy breathes on it, it's game over. So what happened a couple of times was I had units on one side I would have liked to send to fight. But I was unable to send them in a few games and a couple of other times I did send them but they were too slow so it was game over. This doesn't seem like a problem until you have 1 or 2 very weak enemies survive/sneak by and it's just game over. There are some buildings and cards that increase unit speed but overall are a very poor investment compared to economic ones.

TL;DR If you're expecting a relaxing TD feel/base builder like Kingdom Two Crowns you might want to pass on this. If you're interested in card combos and enjoy optimizing a deck this should be a great game.

No amount of strategy or micro will fix the poisoned run - you're just screwed. 

A guaranteed market would certainly help alleviate the problem. I have no idea why the devs haven't made a market a guaranteed early-game drop. IMO, every run should have a market offered within the first 5 rounds.

- I enjoy unlocking different leaders and cards as i'm progressing throughout the game. The leaders definitely add something to your play style and they help shape what you do in your run and i think that it's a great way to provide some more replay value.

Things that annoy me, but probably don't ruin the game for most people.
- After the last wall on either side of the palace is broken, you cannot send troops to stop any enemy units. which means unless you have a bomb card or the legendary adviser that destroys enemies when your base is hit, the game is essentially over at that point. however the game does not end at this point. it can take time for the enemy to break any buildings that you have in that section, and if it's the infected that got in this can be particularly slow. which means you have to sit and wait, knowing you have lost until it becomes official. 
- The draw animation is slow. out of context it probably doesn't appear that slow. but later in the game waves move fast. I've played several runs where i could infinitely play a few cards and redraw them without cost. example: mining for 200+ gold, 2 copies of steal, +1 other card of choice. with no cards in bag you can cycle through these cards for as much money as you want. using your limitless cash use the other card of choice as many times as you'd like. this sounds like it should basically win you the game. infinite money, infinite uses of whatever cards you want. the problem was that the animation for drawing the cards took so long that i couldn't play cards quickly. Even when not attempting infinite loops, i still felt that i was being held back at times by how slow the drawing was. 

Things that i do think are somewhat problematic.
- How successful your run will be feels heavily dependent on what cards you get. There are a lot of cards that i would probably never put in any deck regardless of what strategy i'm going for.  it's also fairly frequent that i open up the market, hit the refresh and still not want a single card. i've had games where i bought 3 market buildings because i knew if i wanted to beat wave 30 there are certain cards you basically need. 
- Depending on which leader you go with, there aren't a lot of different strategies you can go with that feel like they can actually help get you a win.

Reasons i say potentially 5/5
- There is a beta mode in the game called leader mode plus or something like that. It has many more unique cards added. the cards themselves feel more interesting and special. I felt while playing that there was more variety in the decisions i had to make. Basically if they take what's in this beta version and keep working with it, this game would be a 5/5 without any hesitation.

To start off this review, let me ask a question.

Why is Ratropolis a real-time game? Why is it not either an ATB or turn-based game?

I despise the real-time aspect of this game. It is utter lunacy, trying to figure out where to put down buildings, keep track of my troops, play cards from my hand, keep an eye on ALL the fucking timers, look for the merchant, look for active buildings that need to be clicked, and so on!

This game is chaos incarnate. I do not find it at all fun to play. There are so many aspects of its user interface I loathe, too. Where is the 'view my entire current deck' button? Why must I look at my draw pile, and then my hand, and then my discard pile to get an idea of my deck's size? Why can't I view or click any of these things when adding cards to my deck? Why can't I view them while I'm deciding which chest reward to pick or when a random event pops up (always at the most inopportune time)?

Let me give you an example of the timers you have to keep an eye on while playing.

1. Timers for your unit labor. Maybe you'll get some gold or a card draw every X seconds.
2. Timers on your buildings that produce things. Almost no buildings are automatic, so if you don't click them, they just sit there, wasted, forever. Why can't you at least manually set these to automatically pop up or activate?
3. Timers on the next enemy wave(s).
4. Timers on when you can discard your hand without paying gold.
5. A timer for how long the merchant will stick around.
6. Timers for chests before they disappear.
7. An invisible timer for your rat tax, which gives you money every X seconds.

I'm probably not even getting all of them! Each timer you miss has a huge correlation with your early demise!

Why don't purchasable buildings tell you how big they are somewhere on the card's description, and why don't they tell you how many slots you currently have available? If you only have two slots available, buying a three slots building means you just added a useless card into your deck cycle! Genius!

Why can't I purchase the random card from the merchant and have the chance to immediately discard it? It's bad enough the merchant's wares usually suck, but my only shot at getting something decent is almost always a total crapshoot.

Why can't I pause the game and play units or cards? Don't tell me something like that isn't doable. If 'They Are Billions' can add such great QOL features like that, so can this game.

If this game wasn't a manic, unfun, hyperspeed game, or if it had a pause feature where I could just... LOOK at the battlefield, my cards, my hand, and make decent tactical decisions, or if it was turn-based... I would actually rate this game up!

As much as I'd like to validate this game as good, it's... far from there yet. The concept is fun. The execution isn't, at least for now. Graphics and sounds are good.

Besides the EA basics (balancing, missing content), which I do believe will get done, in my opinion this game has are fundamental gameplay issues.

1) Unit stacking. As you may have noticed from the presentation video, units have no "body", they can stack on top of each other as if they were nothing. Your units and the enemy. That means that they can form a blob, which instagibs everything, somewhat at random. Enemy units tend to come one by one, so that's what your units do. To counteract this, the devs have implemented AOE damage, which... decimates those blobs. On both sides. There should be a limitation to the number of units on a position, to reduce the power of AOE and insta-gib blobs.
2) Infinite stacking. There are card which add bonus to your unit cards in game. Permanently. This a huge no-go for me for game based on CCG mechanics, as it always ended in failure. Other cards add permanent bonuses to gold generation.

Others things I think are missing, but I doubt they'll be in game:

3) Maybe I missed it, but I failed to see a way to separate your armies at a tower.
4) Power level feedback. Basically, the game let you position units at a tower, and enemy waves come from the left, right, or both at each wave. The warning gives you the number of enemies like this : 1x unknown, 5x unknown, 3x unknown. Over your units, the only things you have are small icons, and a number telling you how many each of them are. However, units go from 5 to 400 HP, from 2-3 attack to more than 50. Also, the units you placed may have different stats depending on how, when, where you put them. So, none of that gives you an accurate information of whether you'll win or not.
5) Complete rework of repair mechanics. Repairing consist in clicking on a building and waiting for 5 seconds that it repairs. You have to remain still for those 5 seconds. Later in the game, enemy bombards your buildings and can break a half a dozen of those in a single wave, and waves come about every 30 seconds. There are building that made repairing faster, but that's a band-aid on a bad game flow.
6) building rebuilding. Maybe I missed it, but I couldn't demolish my own buildings to make place for new ones.
7) a way to make housings and towers to expand more reliable. You can get a run completely lost just because you don't enough of those. Housings are what limit the number of soldiers you can have. I blocked, at first, at maximum level 26 (with a lot of losses lower). I started buying those everytime they appeared and made 2 runs at 29 and 30.

So I don't recommend it. I finished it for the challenge, but I didn't have fun. Maybe it'll get better.

67428297.review:
It's a fun game, and it has some very fun mechanics, but it feels like there's only a specific way to really win: hope you get a crossbowrat (for their piercing effect) or a musketrat (for high damage), some way to tank damage (either invest in LOTS of totems or get a shieldbearer), and find a means of upgrading your soldiers' damage and health. Because it's a rogue-like deckbuilder, you only have a slim chance of ever seeing any of those cards. Everything else is barely necessary. Your soldiers will go down too quickly to defend late game if you can't buff them, you can't buff them if you don't get the right cards, and you can't get the right cards when your deck is cluttered and/or you don't get good drops after each wave.

In other Deckbuilders, like Slay the Spire, each card complements a new tactic or playstyle. In Ratropolis, each card is necessary in some way, leaving you struggling to make space for new buildings, earn money, and manage your population, while ensuring you have a good hand to play during the next wave. If you get a hand full of weak soldiers during a tough boss fight, or buildings you can't place because you have no space to do so, you're forced to discard them. It's made worse still if you need either a military or building card, but you have a hand of useless cards (such as skills that should only be played during combat), and you have no means of using them.

Your downtime is often spent rushing for cards and trying to juggle where some buildings should go. their placement is semi-permanent, meaning that if you accidentally slip and put it in the wrong place, you've just screwed yourself if you have a building card that requires a large space (like a horn or a ballista). Your best bet is getting a demolition card, but good luck getting that before the next wave and not burning through your money on early redraws.

I've finished it twice, and while I did enjoy those playthroughs (and will continue to play it on and off - a negative review where the player can't stop, shocking, I know), the game feels much too cluttered with its mechanics and must be played in a specific way; with a heavy reliance on military. It doesn't feel like you're allowed to try any different strategies.

For early access, there is a lot to love in this game. It has low system requirements for older systems, the design and theme are amazing, and the game concept is wickedly interesting. I enjoy how the game combines deck building with a tower defense strategy game. As an early access game, there is a lot of polish here - point in case, I've only had one small 'bug' where my cursor occasionally goes a little bonkers and can be reset by just hitting escape twice.

That said, there's still a lot of room for growth here. The game really only has one real win strategy - build up a ton of gold and only hire a couple of specific troops to smash your way through the end boss. There's also no real difference in difficulty levels. When you also account for the fact that the level 30 'end boss' is insanely difficult compared with other mobs, it's easy to see the tuning that needs to take place.

My other big ding is that the game really lacks replayability. Due to the lack of win conditions, once you've played once, it feels like that's the entirety of the game. Even the micro rewards of new cards with the xp system feel pointless because they only get in the way of the cards that are most useful. If the developers added in some new victory paths, a set of challenges maps, and maybe introduced a couple co-op modes such as versus or a split invasion defense this game would be truly amazing.

More than anything though, with the progression system I want to be able to build custom decks. The current game mode relies heavily on random card drops. It could be way more fun to have limited decks based on the different heroes that I could cultivate as I powered through the game with rare unlocks for completing each storyline. This would really let me feel a sense of progression and involvement.

62761513.review:
[b] Overview [/b]
I seem to be dipping into the card mechanics pretty heavily over the last few months, starting with my addiction to Slay the Spire and most recently spending a good amount of time with Trials of Fire. Ratropolis pleasantly surprised me yet again and is now the newest of the genre to soak up my free time when I had initially gone into it not entirely sure of what to expect. After only the first couple of games, I realized that it’s another title to earn a spot among my favorites for its unique blend of real-time and deck-building elements, a combination that is so well done that I’ve played at least two games of it every day since I first got my hands on it.


[b] Enter the Rat Race [/b]
Ratropolis is played in games that last anywhere from a couple of minutes to half an hour depending on how well you hold off the enemies of ratkind (other rats, weasels, and even reptiles) that seek to raze your city. Waves of increasing strength arrived every minute and you must fight them off with the resources that you have at your disposal. Fortunately, each wave provides a treasure chest upon being defeated that rewards you with a choice of useful boons, such as adding or removing cards from your deck, increasing the efficiency of your leader, or even building a new house to boost the population of your rats and the taxes that make up your income. The occasional boss wave offers an even more impressive selection of rewards, though you certainly earn them as they are a significant threat to your settlement.

Due to the real-time nature of the game, drawing a new hand of cards is restricted not by turns, but by a timer. You can pay a hefty sum of coins to skip the timer and instantly draw, but even the richest of cities will struggle financially if this is used too often. There are plenty of times where it’s worth it though, an immediate hand or two in an emergency can be the difference between surviving a wave and being overwhelmed by it.


[b] Hoarding For Survival [/b]
When you first begin, you some open land with your capital building centered on it, and a wall on either side of it. The direction that the settlement goes from here is determined by the cards that you use, and they come in for primary categories: economy, building, military, and skill. Other than in rare instances, cards always cost gold, and sometimes other resources such as your population. Economy cards tend to focus on making money in one way or another. Building cards are single-use cards that construct permanent structures on your open land or expand it further with new walls at predetermined locations. These tend to offer powerful activated abilities and useful passives, though they’re a fairly uncommon find and the most impressive of them are also expensive. Military cards create units at a wall of your choice, each consumes one of your population (or more if they’re particularly powerful) as well as their cost in coins. Unit types are varied and plentiful, but you’ll often struggle with your available population due to the increasingly stronger defenses that you need; housing is more than worth its weight in gold. Finally, skill cards are used for an instant effect, such as a battle cry that buffs military units for a short time, or another that sets an area on fire dealing damage to all units that pass through it until it burns out. I was pleased with the assortment in every category, and gaining new cards never stops being exciting.


[b] King of the Rats [/b]
Each game of Ratropolis starts with you selecting a leader, though you’ll only be able to use the merchant in your first game as you’ll unlock the rest by hitting milestones later. The roster currently includes the merchant, the general, the building, the scientist, and the shaman, though there is at least one more coming by the final release. Each of these comes with an activated ability and a passive benefit. The merchant can discard cards to generate additional gold for your treasury based on the amount of gold currently in it, while they also reduce the purchase price of new cards from merchants and the market. The general can strengthen any military cards in their hand, and every such card in their deck increases the population of your settlement. The builder can discard their hand to acquire building cards that must be built before drawing the new hand, and building cards, in general, can be played on buildings of the same type to upgrade them. The scientist can generate skill cards that must be used immediately, though the use of any such card will reduce the timer on their ability making it available frequently if you have a good number of them in your deck. The last of those currently available, the shaman, specializes in the soul resource and can use it as a currency to acquire a number of useful benefits. With leaders that suit a wide variety of playstyles, I’ve found that I can play several games in quick succession without losing interest and I’m looking forward to whatever others may be added to the game in the future.


[b] Verdict [/b]
Ratropolis is easy to learn, but a challenge to master, and every game feels different from the last. Although some have offered solid competition for Slay the Spire’s crown at the top of the genre, none have come as close to Ratropolis for me, and that’s saying something as it’s still in Early Access. I highly recommend it to anyone who likes the concept, particularly if you’re into card-based mechanics, as I’d already classify it as an indie gem even in its current state. The only warning that I would give is that its real-time aspect keeps you on your toes and rushing about, sometimes even making you feel overwhelmed depending on the situation at hand. If you don’t need that kind of stress in your life and would prefer games that are slower-paced, this one may not be what you’re looking to pick up as your next purchase.

61322163.review:
A very tentative recommendation.  In terms of my play-time, I've completed most content (including wave 120), so I feel I've enough experience with the game to give a moderately informed review. 

In a nutshell, this game is a very polished game that reminds me of my days playing free games in the heyday of flash.  Take a Newgrounds defense game and add a massive layer of professionalism and that's this game.  You play a defense game where your units, economy, and development are linked to a deck built throughout a session.  It is hard.  You will lose a lot.  But there will be an "ah-hah!" moment where you understand what the game wants from you and suddenly it will be rare to lose.

Strengths:
-- Presentation: Adorable mice set against a backdrop of a grimly brutal world, what's not to love?  UI is simple and could have a few QoL additions but does the job just fine.  Soundwise the voice "acting" is amusing and cute, but otherwise unremarkable.

-- Gameplay Loop: For the first 20-30 hours, there's enough variety to satisfy even veterans of games like Slay the Spire.  Like Slay, you can work your way towards some absurd "combos".  It's quite satisfying to see a wave melt after a single twang of your crossbow rats or having a single "Greatest Rat" wipe the floor with a boss.  Beyond that, however, and the lack of depth is clearly shown and going for the harder achievements really lays bare the weaknesses of the game.  Continual updates should stave that off (though the most recent one, the Shaman, does not).

-- Usability: The game runs really, really smoothly.  The polish in the game (barring the somewhat poor yet charming English translation) shines through.  Cards come and go naturally and the game, in general, works without any issues.

Negatives:

-- Difficulty: The difficulty curve in this game, right now, is jarring.  A unit composition may smash one wave and be overrun the next.  A lot of this is down to the RNG present in the game.  Waves can spawn on 1 side only, meaning all of the enemies on that side get doubled up and can really mug you if you're already falling behind the curve.  It's very feast or famine but has improved since it's initial steam release.  Won't touch much on nightmare mode, as I truly believe it's meant for masochists.  My run took me ~6hrs, mostly just clicking between barracks to slowly upgrade units. 

-- Odd Choices: A catch-all, but largely it refers to your ability to control your units in game.  It's not uncommon to see half your melee units fighting the mobs whilst the rest of your forces stand there picking their noses.  You have no direct control over them.  This makes certain units almost entirely useless simply due to the AI controlling their actions, Medics are especially poor due to this.  Similarily, moving units is incredibly painful as you can't set them to go to a specific wall, just up or down one wall.  These are largely minor issues, but have wiped a couple of runs for me.

Overall, it's a niche game.  If you like hard games and you like defense games then this is right up your alley.  You will have to forgive some minor issues but you should get solid enjoyment for the price.  Recommended.

At the time of writing this review the game was on patch 1.0.3102 and I can say that in its current state I would recommend this game despite its rough edges.

The game is HARD at best and brutally UNFAIR at worst. The blending of deckbuilding and RTS is a fun mechanic and pulling off neat combos of cards feels great. Though as many other folks have said there are some cards that simply feel too weak to feel happy playing. In other deckbuilding games the main RNG factors are whether or not you get the right cards or items, in Ratropolis you also have to deal with the RNG of which side the enemies attack from. In the early stages this isn’t much of an issue as you can move your troops from one side to the other but once you build up your empire this isn’t a feasible strategy. Having a balance of forces on either side is also a viable strategy but when the mid to late game bosses spawn you basically have to pray they spawned on the side with the most troops.

Balance wise each of the leaders do offer slightly different playstyles but some of the powers do feel lacking. The Merchants R ability ranges from ‘meh’ to ‘okay’ depending on how much money you have. The Shamans ability would be great but it feels like half the soul-siphon cards are pretty weak unless you stockpile absurd amounts of Souls onto them. 
The advisors offer nice bonuses that range from passive ‘good’ effects to bonuses that shape your run entirely. That being said I think it would be nice to have some way to buy an advisor, relying on the events and legendary chests yet again makes it feel like youre at the mercy of the games RNG system.

That being said when you get the nut combos the game really feels fun some of my favourite combos have been: 
-	As the General Leader, Train + Arm + Rally. The combo of your hero power plus the skill cards allows you to get some truly beefy troops.
-	As the Builder Leader, Tavern/s + Totem lvl 2. Using the Tavern ability to duplicate cards you get to the point where you are reducing the attacks of enemies to the point where they do next to no damage. Other leaders can pull this off, but the Builder has an easier time hitting the combo.
-	As the Scientist Leader, Ignite + Shock + Agit. An obvious combo but stunning enemies and watching them burn Is a nice combo and it gives your soldiers a nice day off. Using support cards like Tracking allow you to hit the combo more reliable. 
At the time of this review I still haven’t completed all of the achievements and I am still having fun trying to complete them all. Hopefully the developers stay passionate about this project and continue development into 2020. 

Solid foundation, with some rough edges that need smoothing but still a fun experience.

The gameplay loop in Ratropolis is to play economy cards for gold, and to spend this gold on military units to defend against waves of enemies. There's a little extra going on with ratizens and needing to upgrade soldiers, but for the most part this is your gameplay loop. The problem is that each of these things are extremely samey.

The first problem is that all economy cards essentially function as if the text said, "Play this card for gold." Sometimes you might get gold just for playing a card. Maybe you'll get gold for playing the same card many times, or you'll get gold if you click an ore mine for so many seconds. Most of the economy cards are not as good as others, so you'll be playing this 'solitaire' minigame with the same subset of cards for the majority of your time.

The second problem is that your military units are almost all functionally the same. They're stat sticks with maybe an effect that heals the other rats, or slows down enemies, or roots an enemy in place. None of these things are very fun or interesting in practice because of the point I'm going to bring up.

Enemies come in deathballs, and while sure it says they have an ability, all it really comes down to when they crash into your wall is if you have a certain amount of stats split on your military units defending. If you do, you'll crush the wave in about 10 seconds. If you don't, the wave which is probably about 20 units doing the same attack animation right on top of each other, is barreling down to your center and you've lost. There is no way to really interact with your enemies other than through your stat sticks, and there's no reason to learn what each enemy does because it absolutely does not matter. In fact, you shouldn't really be paying attention at all to the fights, as it's more efficient to simply be playing the solitaire economy minigame at all times.

You can play as different leaders, but they don't really change any of the problems I have. The trader can make more gold. The general can buff military units. The shaman can remind you that you would be having more fun playing Transformice than Ratropolis. Overall, any of the fun I had with Ratropolis was at the most superficial level and while I really wanted to enjoy it, it just failed at every level for me.

The biggest problem with the game is that it offers a wide variety of ways to play, if of course you enjoy losing. If you want to win, there's really only one or two viable strategies you can run, each relying heavily on RNG to give you the cards you need. And your reward for lasting longer once those cards are given to you? Naturally, it's unlocking more cards and making the select few good ones even harder to find.
A variety of small problems, which on their own are harmless, but when added together just amount to a devastating feeling of dissatisfaction after every loss (and often wins too) is the lack of an ability to move individual units should a wall need reinforcements which can have crippling effects, and being unable to send any units to destroyed walls. This effectively means as soon as any one inner-wall is breached, its game over regardless of your troop count or hand because you can't get move them to the fight or spawn troops at the main building.What's the point of making the enemies spend time attacking buildings within those walls if delaying them has literally no positive effect except elongating the feeling of helplessness with each loss?   
And should you try to use building abilities during any point of this chaos, you'll find yourself scrolling back and forth over the playing field to find what your looking for. Honestly, with this mechanic, it seems the game tried to instill a necessity for skillful multitasking but its delivery is nothing short of an annoying tedium because the multitasking is exactly that: a task. A simple bar somewhere on the screen with all active abilities listed that could be clicked would be a simple solution, but seeing as it would undermine the chaotic focus of the game, I doubt it'd be implemented.
Of course, you can try to organize the buildings to make it easier to find what you're looking for, but don't expect to get very far. You often aren't in control of what buildings cards you get and when you can play them, and if you delay placement for some hope of order, you'll often find that such a simple plan ends the game for you. 
Adding to the calamity is how easily certain enemies can wipe out your units. Don't have enough militia early game but have a lot of guards? Well, watch as with a single jump over your wall that entire reserve of ranged units is wiped out by a monster. And if you do have enough melee troops? Sit back and enjoy the later game monsters pulverize them all with their AoE.

The game's concept started strong when I first started playing. Having to divert focus a million different ways nonstop was at first pleasant test of one's capabilities, but after playing for a while you'll find yourself feeling as though you did everything right and still came up short. And when you do finally figure out the magic combination of cards needed to last, you'll find that its the ONLY combination of cards that really works. Overall, this when combined with the many small nuisances found in some of the game mechanics makes the game frustrating to lose and boring to win. That being said, it's a no from me.

The game is still in early access, but already worth its salt!

Ratropolis is a simple base-building, base-defense rogue lite. You have a deck with cards ranging from economy over buildings and skills to military rats. You have to balance your economy with infrastructure and defense to make it through waves of mean cats, crocs and other miscreants wanting to destroy your civilisation. After a wave you get options to personalize your deck or improve your city/economy. 

Games take between 10-45 minutes, but strategies are very varied, giving it high-replayability value. The art-style and music are great, controls are almost flawless, and the game is generally well-balanced, although there are a few "dead" runs, where I think it is impossible to get beyond the wave 20 mark.

My only major gripe with the game in its current form is that there is no way to reduce the pool of available cards, and some of these cards are pretty damn useless. It doesn't feel nice when finally the trader comes around, but doesn't hold a single card that could be useful for the strategies you opened yourself up. - I don't think being able to build a complete deck is a good idea either, but maybe being able to ban 5-10 cards in the beginning would solve that issue.

Otherwise, the game is a wholehearted recommendation from my side.

I was instantly hooked on this game after seeing a youtuber, Wabderbots, play the demo. I am a huge fan of slay the spire and many other deck building games, and Kingdoms was okay for me, though I thought it may have been a little slow. This game really does a great job of combining the better aspects of both games. However, as much as I do love this game it does have some issues and some things it can improve upon. For starters this game's biggest issue is its balancing and scaling. This game brings a unique opportunity to bring your cards to life but the enemies just scale up way too quickly, and abruptly. I can name 4 distinct spots where the game has a major spike in difficulty, that being waves 13, 15, 26, and 30. These waves will, 9 out of 10 times, be your downfall. One this Wanderbots repeats in his lets-play of this series is that this should be an endless wave game that gradually scales, and I completely agree with this. That is the only major issue I have with this game, but I do hope that it adds more leaders, cards, and maybe even mod compatibility in the future. 

Please don't let my major criticism deter you from at least giving this game a try. This game is lovely and you can progress through it even if you aren't able to beat all 30 waves, which isn't impossible I have done it. This is an issue which can be fixed later in development, so much so that it may even be a non-issue by the time this game is fully released. It is, to my knowledge and experience, a unique game that builds on its best aspects very well and I do recommend giving it a try, especially since its only $15. There is a lot of potential for this game and many core aspects that it does well that it can build off of. Do however take the initial gameplay with a grain of salt as it is an early access game. Not that its bad, but at the moment  it is pretty limited.

The problem with this game is that you are completely screwed if you don't get incredible RNG. Good rogue likes are difficult but possible to beat 60-80% of the time if you understand how the game works. This game requires you to get lucky and find certain cards that allow you to make it past even the middle 10 waves. The game scales wildly every 10 stages ramping up the difficulty several times over. Some of the best cards in the game require you to unlock them by playing every character through several runs. Unlockables in roguelikes should open up new play styles, not just straight up give you more power.

Other than having all the right cards drop for you or appear in the shop the only other bit of skill comes in the form of an APM check and your ability to guess what's happening on one side of your settlement while looking elsewhere. You can zoom all the way out and see everything but the icons don't get any bigger on buildings with active abilities so they're near impossible to click on. Could do with some extra keybinds for active abilities like the aid station and some QoL changes to make doing what you want easier. I know what I need to do, it's just a pain in the ass to do it which makes it less fun.

Card upgrades making the cards more expensive is needlessly confusing on the part of economy cards. If the price goes up 10 and the gold gain goes up 20, why not just keep the price the same and only make the gold gain go up by 10? It makes it just that much more difficult to comeback if you fall behind even a little bit. If you lose one wall ever you are fucked and might as well give up the run so long as you're past wave 10 already. You'll know if you're going to go far in the run or not after the first 5 or 6 waves. If you aren't though you can't just abandon the run because there's an event that requires you to make it past wave 10 on the previous run. If you didn't the event does nothing which means you're missing out on the possible benefits from a different event.

The game draws you in with a visual style similar to Kingdom and the Roguelike Deckbuilding genere of Slay the Spire but it doesn't deliver any of the feelings those games do.

I'd be willing to check it out again in the future to see if things have improved at all but for now I'm just not enjoying the game.

6/10.

Pros:
I love the theme (I like rodent based games), the art, the homage to Slay the Spire, and the mechanic of deckbuilding and card dragging.  And I liked the idea of base-building  a physical village with cards. 

Cons:  This is a mash up of Slay the Spire with a 2D side-scrolling RTS and for me, I guess I just don't love that chocolate in my peanut butter.  If you truly love Slay the Spire, a mechanic that requires you to rapidly mash buttons is probably going to be anathema. And the deckbuilding itself is only ok --for example, I felt you always had to make this binary choice as to whether you are going to use cheese as your economic engine, or strip it out of your deck and try to make money with killing or mining or being a slum lord. And leaving that last cheese for the discard every time feels kind of clunky.

This is a review on how the game needs balancing. I've read the other reviews and think the well thought out ones speak to the pros and cons of this game, so I don't feel the need to repeat what others have said. What I would like to add however is that the game is currently not very fun because of how useless almost every card is. I am almost considering resetting my game before the unlocks so that I don't have to deal with all the absolutely terrible cards clogging up the merchant. There is no way to build synergies unless you get incredibly lucky, so 'winning' just requires playing over and over and over and over until you get everything to line up just right. Until something is done to improve the game, I cannot recommend it.

[h1]Constructive thoughts[/h1]
I believe a few things need to be done to help the game:

[b]1) Completely change how military is handled.[/b]
Right now you place military cards down on little outposts and allow them to defend you until they die. You can keep placing cards until you're out of rat population, so you're limited on card draw, owning units, and rat population. All of that is fine. What isn't fine is that your military is never strong enough to handle anything in the later stages unless you're lucky enough to have gotten the building that constantly improves a unit or a large amount of the few useful skill cards (and both cases are fairly rare).  

[b]Proposed Change:[/b]
Make military respawn after death and make every wall use an independent housing cap. This makes it so you have a reason to populate the inner walls with military, and it also makes it so you don't just instantly lose to the end stages and can potentially come back if your strong outer wall is breached. It gives the game more strategic value.

Secondly, a way to buff currently placed military is needed. I really enjoy the idea of continuously buffing a few cards on the super rare chance that I have gotten the building to do so, but by the time you are able to play even a couple of them, there are too few of them to make a difference against the insanely strong enemies. If already placed units could gain permanent buffs with cards, you can have real scaling that attempts to keep pace with the enemy scaling.

[b]2) Remove, change, or buff all the cards that are useless.[/b]
Most of the skill cards are terrible. The damaging cards are amazing mid game, but (like pretty much everything), they are absolutely worthless late game. They badly need some sort of scaling to keep up with the late game. Don't get me wrong on this section however, as some of the best cards in the game are actually skill cards (like research, forge, and I'm forgetting what other one). But the skill cards also have some of the worst in the game.

Economy cards are mostly pretty solid. There are a few different econ routes you can take, and I like that part being totally random. Some games a cheese route is good just because you were offered cheeses and methods of slimming your cards down or drawing a lot. Other games it's better to have a huge rat population and use delayed money cards. Still others you tax your population into submission. 

The building cards are also fairly solid, but some changes should be made here as well. Buildings are the only thing that "scale" into the end game by the fact that you can just keep building more of them, and most of their abilities are useful to have more of. The only issue is that the amount of cards in the game and the few times you're offered cards means you don't usually get many buildings unless you're the builder. I don't think you should be reaching builder levels of building offers, but something needs to be done to make this be the main stable aspect of the set.

[b]3) Card offers need to be increased.[/b]
Right now there are too many cards, and most of them don't help you. I believe the chests should offer the same thing they do now, but they should also always give you 3 cards to choose from. Yes, this means you can choose the 3 cards option and get two sets of 3 cards to choose from. As of now, it is not possible to build synergies unless you're lucky, which strips away the little strategy this game could have.

[b]End Thoughts.[/b]
I write all of this not in disappointment at the game. That would be a waste of time. I believe this game has great potential. It just needs a lot of polishing to reach that potential. I also don't think my suggestions are the end all be all fixes (or even necessarily the root problems of the game). There are many options that could make the game shine. I just hope something is done that gives the player more strategic options rather than making very few actual choices and relying on luck.
